results.title: Mysterious Australia: The shaping of Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
A journey through the puzzles that nature used as it designed and shaped the Australian continent. The story criss-crosses the continent discovering the world’s oldest living organisms and how sea fossils three hundred million years old came to be on a mountain top hundreds of kilometres from the ocean.

results.title: The Islands of Torres Strait
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
Torres Strait is a treacherous waterway between Cape York, the northern most tip of the Australian mainland and Papua New Guinea. The shallow strait is dotted with Islands and coral outcrops. From Possession Island at the southern extremity, Captain James Cook formally laid claim to the Australian colonies in the name of England. Later the Queensland Government moved to control the Islands of the Strait and their people. Once, the islanders currency of trade was human heads, and headhunting raids between the islands and mainland Papua New Guinea was part of life. On this journey through the islands, Ted Egan meets some old friends, sees dugout canoes being built and meets the keeper of the legendary Drums of Mer.

results.title: Broome and the Pearl Coast
results.creator_credit: Martyn Down, John Mabey, Rhonda Mabey, AFFC and Sorena
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
Broome, in the remote north-west of Australia is famous for its pearling industry. Travelling the breadth of the Pearl Coast, Ted Egan encounters a number of extraordinary people like Yoshinori Maeda who came to Australia as a young man to fish, but decided to stay. The vast panoramic coast and desert of the north-west is explored, including the beautiful splendour of Deepwater Point, 200kms from Broome.

results.title: Discovering a rainforest
results.creator_credit: Kenyon Castle, John Mabey and Rhonda Mabey
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
The first part of the Australian continent to be touched by the morning sun is the sentinel peak of Mt. Warning, the core of an ancient volcano. In the eroded valleys and rugged mountain ranges that surround the peak are some of the world’s most beautiful rainforests, just a short journey from Surfers Paradise, Australia’s tourist playground. Sandwiched between the ocean and the outer rim of the volcano exists an incredible pot pourri of people and lifestyles.

results.title: Central Australia: The Eighth Wonder
results.creator_credit: Martyn Down, John Mabey, Rhonda Mabey and Sorena P
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
A visual kaleidoscope of the Red Centre’s picturesque wonders. It is also the part of Australia that Ted Egan calls home. Australia’s foremost bush storyteller takes us on a journey through a landscape where travel is still an adventure.

results.title: Railways of yesteryear
results.creator_credit: John Mabey, Rhonda Mabey and Sorena
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
A must for all railway enthusiasts; a journey into the past on trains from the “golden age of steam” and through some of Australia’s most spectacular and breathtaking scenery. We ride the famous Zig Zag in the Blue Mountains (NSW), see three steam trains race side by side on modern suburban tracks in Sydney, watch Puffing Billy steaming its way through the Dandenong Ranges (Vic), then across to SA for an ambling trip on Australia’s first public railway line - the old horse-drawn tram in Victor Harbour, the Pichi Richi railway in the Flinders Ranges and finally the ultimate - a trip on both the Old and the New Ghan across Central Australia providing a glimpse of the past and the future. Narrated by Ted Eagan.

results.title: Norfolk Island: From Hell to Paradise
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
Norfolk Island is an eight by six kilometre paradise set in the blue waters of the South West Pacific Ocean about 1,500 kilometres east of the Australian mainland. The island was secured by the British in 1788 just a few weeks after settlement at Sydney Cove. It was abandoned after a few years, until 1824 when it became one of the most terrible and feared penal settlements. The graveyards and chronicles testify to the brutality and terror of those awful years. The island was abandoned but eventually re-settled by descendants of the Bounty mutineers who moved there from the more isolated Pitcairn Island in 1856.

results.title: The Snowy Mountains
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Land Australia with Ted Egan”.
Ted Egan takes up the Snowy Mountains story 100 years after Australia’s favourite poet, Banjo Paterson, immortalised a young mountain horseman in his epic poem, “The Man From Snowy River”. Features the pioneering development and the lifestyle of the mountain’s people, including the historic construction of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Scheme. Filmed over the four seasons, the story also includes an aerial kaleidoscope of the high country from spring to winter with spectacular displays of wild flowers and fragile alpine wilderness.

results.title: Screen magazine. No. 02
results.creator_credit: Leo Herwood and United Nations. Film Board
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This is the United Nations”.
Cinemagazine items: 1. Acting President Romulo urges accord on atomic energy - The film opens with a shot of the atomic bomb bursting over Hiroshima on a day in August 1945. The two plans suggested for the control of atomic energy are illustrated by simple drawings. 2. Unique method of interpretation assists at United Nations meeting - Interpreters with the ability to listen to speeches in one language and interpret it instantly, sentence by sentence, into another language have greatly aided the problem of understanding. 3. The United Nations Internatinal Childrens Emergency Fund (UNICEF) helps feed 6,000,000 - Film shows how UNICEF is helping to alleviate the hunger of starving children all over the world.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Leo Herwood and United Nations. Film Board

Cinemagazine items: 1. Acting President Romulo urges accord on atomic energy - The film opens with a shot of the atomic bomb bursting over Hiroshima on a day in August 1945. The two plans suggested for the control of atomic energy are illustrated by simple drawings. 2. Unique method of interpretation assists at United Nations meeting - Interpreters with the ability to listen to speeches in one language and interpret it instantly, sentence by sentence, into another language have greatly aided the problem of understanding. 3. The United Nations Internatinal Childrens Emergency Fund (UNICEF) helps feed 6,000,000 - Film shows how UNICEF is helping to alleviate the hunger of starving children all over the world.
description_for_label:
Episode of Series “This is the United Nations”.
Cinemagazine items: 1. Acting President Romulo urges accord on atomic energy - The film opens with a shot of the atomic bomb bursting over Hiroshima on a day in August 1945. The two plans suggested for the control of atomic energy are illustrated by simple drawings. 2. Unique method of interpretation assists at United Nations meeting - Interpreters with the ability to listen to speeches in one language and interpret it instantly, sentence by sentence, into another language have greatly aided the problem of understanding. 3. The United Nations Internatinal Childrens Emergency Fund (UNICEF) helps feed 6,000,000 - Film shows how UNICEF is helping to alleviate the hunger of starving children all over the world.
